PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Formation of chimera states in complex systems
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Chamada CNPq N � 12/2017 - Bolsas de Produtividade em Pesquisa - PQ - Processo: 310124/2017-4 -
The synchronization effects are a common phenomenon in networks with applications in several areas, such as in biological systems and neuroscience, engineering, economics and social sciences. More recently, the possibility of simultaneous coexistence was observed in a single network incoherent states (not synchronized) and coherent (synchronized). This coexistence of coherent and incoherent states ere called chimera states. The existence of these chimeras states has applications in neural networks like in the case of certain species of birds remain in a semi-alert state in which part of the brain fall asleep (synchronized state) while another part remains active (non-synchronized state). In this project we will analyze a neural model using the Hindmarsh-Rose equations. As a proposal of coupling, we will use the human synaptic matrix, and we will use the recurrence plot ( it recurrence plot), since it detects the possible collective patterns and their transitions of states that emerge in coupled systems: coherent / synchronized, incoherent and chimera states.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Characteristics of chimera states and applications
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: ?Programa Uk Academies - Research Mobility? (Coopera��o Fundo Newton - Confap - Arauc�ria) - We intend to study configurations favouring the coherent and incoherent states, for the synchronization of spikes and bursts and therefore the emergence of chimera states in a network of neurons that are connected with the topology of the human synaptic connectivity matrix. To identify emerging behaviours we will use the techniques of recurrence adapted to the study of neuronal activity through the spatial recurrence matrix. This technique consists in analysing the existing patterns when we take the spatial profile of the coupled oscillators as a basis. Thus, vertical or horizontal lines indicate small (or not) changes in the dynamic behaviour of the elements of the network, the diagonal lines are related to nodes of the network, in different positions, that behave similarly. The formation of blocks on the scattered or absent points (gaps) indicate and incoherent region. Thus, the blocks along the main diagonal and the gaps provide us with the signature of the chimera states in the system.

Estes sistemas podem exibir v�rios comportamentos de din�mica n�o linear interessantes: sincroniza��o com din�mica temporal ca�tica ou peri�dica, n�o sincroniza��o, e, mais recentemente, foi observado � possibilidade de coexist�ncia simult�nea destes dois comportamentos em uma �nica rede, a exist�ncia de estados sincronizados e n�o sincronizados que foram denominados por estados quimera. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Forma��o de clusters e estados quimera em sistemas complexos
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Chamada CNPq N� 09/2020 - Bolsas de Produtividade em Pesquisa - PQ - Processo:311168/2020-5 : Network synchronization is a collective phenomenon that emerges from interactions between its individual elements. This phenomenon is observed in different areas of applications such as power generation, neuron firing, economic indicators and chemical reactions. In addition to the synchronization phenomenon, the possibility of
simultaneous coexistence of two distinct behaviors in a single network was observed, the existence of 
 synchronized and non-synchronized states that were called chimera states. Another possibility is the formation of clusters in networks, in which parts of the network can be organized in synchronized sets. The coexistence of synchronization and non-synchronization are observed in some diseases such as Parkinson?s, epileptic seizure and Alzheimer?s. Three main points are highlighted here in the execution of this project: (i) Neural network models will be analyzed numerically and investigate the routes and conditions for the formation of chimera states and clusters; (ii) Diagnostics such as the bivariate order parameter and recurrence plot will be developed for the detection and analysis of these phenomena. In particular, the formation of clusters will be developed specific diagnoses for its characterization; (iii) investigation of other models with two-dimensional couplings and the formation of chimera states. The development of these highlighted points, provide an essential role in how the organization of networks of complex systems self-organize emerges. Its potential applications in neural networks and other network models with different coupling topologies will be analyzed.
